elements.content: It is still challengeable to develop a nonprecious bifunctional electrocatalyst for both hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions (HER and OER), with higher efficiency and superior durability over the benchmark noble-metal-based electrocatalysts. To address such issues, for the first time, we design and synthesize FeNi3–Fe3O4 heterogeneous nanoparticles (NPs) homogenously anchored on a matrix of metal-organic framework (MOF) nanosheets and carbon nanotubes (FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT) by a facile hydrothermal reaction and subsequent partial decomposition of a low-cost and earth-abundant Ni/Fe/C precursor. Due to its unique porous nanoarchitecture constructed by ultrafine nanoparticles anchored on two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets/one-dimensional (1D) CNT matrix, it can be employed as a bifunctional electrocatalyst with superior electrocatalytic activity for water splitting: it delivers a small Tafel slope of 37 mV/dec for OER and requires only a very low overpotential of 234 mV to obtain 10 mA/cm2; it has a very low overpotential of 108 mV for HER and also shows an ultralow overpotential of 360 mV to reach 10 mA/cm2 for overall water splitting by outperforming the precious-metal-based electrocatalysts (Pt/C and RuO2; 393 mV at η10). Moreover, it exhibits excellent long-term stability. This work presents a rational nanoarchitecture design and facile fabrication strategy to obtain nonprecious metal-based electrocatalysts with high efficiency and excellent long-lasting abilities.

elements.content:
FeNi3−Fe3O4 Heterogeneous Nanoparticles Anchored on 2D MOF Nanosheets/1D CNT Matrix as Highly Efficient Bifunctional Electrocatalysts for Water Splitting

Introduction

Utilization of sustainable and renewable green energy sources has gained much attention due to the energy crisis and environmental destruction caused by burning fossil fuels. Hydrogen has received enormous attention as one of the clean and sustainable energy sources, which can be produced in the pure form by an electrochemical water-splitting reaction (H2O → H2 + 1/2O2). However, the real-world applications of water-splitting processes are limited by the efficiency of electrocatalysts used for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which are the two core processes involved in a water-splitting system. It is known that precious-metal-supported electrocatalysts, including Pt/C (for HER), IrO2, or RuO2 (for OER), are considered as the benchmark electrocatalysts for water splitting. However, their widespread practical applications have been greatly hindered mainly due to the nonavailability, poor long-term stability, and extremely high cost. Therefore, extensive research efforts have been made to develop electrocatalysts based on earth-abundant elements to rectify the aforementioned difficulties in water splitting. The recent innovative efforts and ideal strategies made by material scientists toward the design and discovery of promising electrocatalysts to make the water electrolysis process more effective led to the isolation of an extensive collection of productive and earth-abundant transition-metal-based electrocatalysts. Among them, Fe-, Co-, and Ni-based materials are the extensively studied electrocatalysts for the water-splitting process owing to their terrestrial abundance, straightforward preparation methods, structural stability, and low cost. Particularly in Ni-/Fe-based electrocatalysts, Ni is considered as the active center for the water-splitting process, and the incorporation of Fe could modify the electronic states of Ni (Ni3+/Ni2+) and thereby significantly enhance the electrocatalytic performance.

Introduction

are limited by the efficiency of electrocatalysts used for the hydrogen
evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER),
which are the two core processes involved in a water-splitting system. It is known that precious-metal-supported electrocatalysts, including
Pt/C (for HER), IrO2, or RuO2 (for OER), are
considered as the benchmark electrocatalysts for water splitting.
However, their widespread practical applications have been greatly
hindered mainly due to the nonavailability, poor long-term stability,
and extremely high cost. Therefore, extensive

on earth-abundant elements to rectify the aforementioned difficulties
in water splitting. The recent innovative efforts and ideal strategies made by material
scientists toward the design and discovery of promising electrocatalysts
to make the water electrolysis process more effective led to the isolation

electrocatalysts. Among them, Fe-, Co-, and Ni-based materials are the extensively

elements.content: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a new class of versatile porous materials fabricated by the coordination of various metal ions with tunable organic building blocks, have been acknowledged in a wide range of applications, mainly due to the vast surface area, unique porous architectures, tunable pore size, morphology, and abundant accessible active metal sites. Although a few MOFs have been employed directly as electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction, the stability issues toward long-lasting operational conditions could hinder their widespread applications. Particularly in transition-metal-based MOFs, Fe-doped Ni-MOFs with enhanced electrocatalytic activity have been studied extensively as a new class of materials for the OER in alkaline solutions owing to their surface electronic state modification, unique porosities, well-organized structures, and widespread active centers in the predetermined crystalline frameworks. Despite the extensive OER studies by Ni-/Fe-MOFs, only a very few MOFs have displayed water-splitting abilities. Alternatively, MOF-based materials can be treated as starting materials to produce different types of functional MOF derivatives, including porous carbons, metals and metal oxides, metal phosphides, and metal sulfides, by virtue of high-temperature annealing, which are usually more stable than MOFs in water electrolysis. The direct pyrolysis of MOF materials toward their derivatives appears easily accessible and facile but is not essentially advanced for water electrolysis. Typically, the complete decomposition of MOF results in considerable reduction in its surface area and also destroys its well-organized pore structures, which leads to the production of a bulk phase with sieged active metal sites and obstructs the chemical substances from accessing active centers.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a new class of versatile
porous
materials fabricated by the coordination of various metal ions with
tunable organic building blocks, have been acknowledged in a wide
range of applications, mainly due to the vast surface area, unique
porous architectures, tunable pore size, morphology, and abundant
accessible active metal sites. Although a few MOFs have been employed directly as electrocatalysts
for the oxygen evolution reaction, the stability issues toward long-lasting
operational conditions could hinder their widespread applications. Particularly in transition-metal-based MOFs, Fe-doped Ni-MOFs with
enhanced electrocatalytic activity have been studied extensively as
a new class of materials for the OER in alkaline solutions owing to
their surface electronic state modification, unique porosities, well-organized
structures, and widespread active centers in the predetermined crystalline
frameworks. Despite the
extensive OER studies by Ni-/Fe-MOFs, only a very few MOFs have displayed
water-splitting abilities. Alternatively, MOF-based
materials can be treated as starting materials to produce different
types of functional MOF derivatives, including porous carbons, metals and metal oxides, metal phosphides, and metal sulfides, by virtue of high-temperature annealing, which
are usually more stable than MOFs in water electrolysis. The direct
pyrolysis of MOF materials toward their derivatives appears easily
accessible and facile but is not essentially advanced for water electrolysis. Typically, the complete decomposition of MOF
results in considerable reduction in its surface area and also destroys
its well-organized pore structures, which leads to the production
of a bulk phase with sieged active metal sites and obstructs the chemical
substances from accessing active centers.

elements.content: To address the above issues, we believe that the production of functional nanoparticles (NPs) within the MOF architecture could inherit the advantages of both as-prepared MOFs and their annealed products. Controlled thermal treatment is an impressive method for the isolation of nanoparticles within MOFs, but one has to firmly control the heating parameters to avoid the massive reduction in the MOF surface area and the complete destruction of pore channels. Mixed-metallic MOFs, on controlled thermal treatment, can produce highly active heterogeneous nanoparticles within their architecture, but it is quite challenging to create such structures by any conventional methods. Moreover, developing a bifunctional catalyst for both OER and HER, with higher performance and durability over noble-metal catalysts, is still a challenge. Although quite a few catalysts have demonstrated better performance over noble-metal-based electrocatalysts only in a few aspects, the problem is designing an advanced catalyst that will surpass all of the aspects of precious-metal catalysts in water splitting.

elements.content: Therefore, it is possible to develop extremely active and robust semi-MOF derivatives by combining the advantages of carbon nanotube (CNT) and the partial pyrolysis strategy. Herein, for the first time, we synthesize FeNi3–Fe3O4 heterogeneous nanoparticles homogenously anchored on a matrix of MOF nanosheets and carbon nanotubes (FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT), by a facile hydrothermal reaction and subsequent partial thermal decomposition of NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT. Due to its unique three-dimensional (3D) porous nanoarchitecture fabricated by ultrathin nanoparticles anchored on two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets/one-dimensional (1D) CNT matrix, there are abundant active catalytic sites in the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT hybrid, which makes it a bifunctional electrocatalyst with superior electrocatalytic performance for water splitting. This hybrid delivers an ultralow overpotential of 234 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2 in the OER process on a glassy carbon electrode (GCE), surpassing those of as-prepared NiFe0.5-MOF, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (prepared by partial annealing of NiFe0.5-MOF), commercial RuO2, and the non-noble-metal catalysts reported earlier (Table S1). However, in HER, it displays an overpotential of 108 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2 on a glassy carbon electrode, exceeding all other materials prepared herein. This material also shows better performance in overall water splitting with an overpotential of 360 mV to reach 10 mA/cm2 current density by outperforming the noble-metal catalyst combination (393 mV at η10). Moreover, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT exhibits appreciable stability and performance even after 20 h for long-term OER, HER, and water-splitting processes.

elements.content: Nickel­(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni­(NO3)3·6H2O), iron­(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (1,4-BDC), carbon nanotube paste (5% CNT in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP)), dimethyl formamide, and ethanol were received from Aladdin, Co. Ltd. Ruthenium oxide (reference electrocatalyst) and Nafion were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Ltd. All of the chemicals were used as received; double-distilled water/ethanol mixtures were used as washing solvents throughout the investigations.

Experimental Section
Materials
Nickel­(II)
nitrate hexahydrate (Ni­(NO3)3·6H2O), iron­(III) chloride hexahydrate
(FeCl3·6H2O), 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic
acid (1,4-BDC), carbon nanotube paste (5% CNT in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP)), dimethyl formamide, and ethanol were
received from Aladdin, Co. Ltd. Ruthenium oxide (reference electrocatalyst)
and Nafion were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Ltd. All of the chemicals
were used as received; double-distilled water/ethanol mixtures were
used as washing solvents throughout the investigations.

elements.content: In a typical synthesis of NiFe0.5-MOF, 1,4-BDC (1 mmol, 166 mg), Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 290 mg), and FeCl3·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 135 mg) were added to 36 mL of a mixed solution (32 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) + 2 mL of EtOH + 2 mL of H2O) in a Teflon vessel (100 mL) in sequence. The resulting reaction mixture was allowed to stir for several minutes at ambient temperature to attain a dark-yellow clear solution. Subsequently, the Teflon vessel was transferred to a stainless steel autoclave, placed upright in an oven, and subjected to heat at 150 °C for 6 h, and then it was allowed to cool down naturally. The as-obtained precipitate was collected by centrifugation and was washed several times with ethanol and water followed by freeze-drying for 12 h. A similar procedure was adopted for the preparation of NiFe0.75-MOF and NiFe0.25-MOF, except for using different molar ratios of FeCl3·6H2O (0.75 and 0.25 mmol) at the beginning.

elements.content: In a typical synthesis of NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT, 1,4-BDC (1 mmol, 166 mg), Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 290 mg), FeCl3·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 135 mg), and 1 g of carbon nanotube (5 wt % in NMP) conductive paste were added to 36 mL of a mixed solution (32 mL of DMF + 2 mL of EtOH + 2 mL of H2O) in a Teflon vessel (100 mL) in sequence. The resulting reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 30 min at ambient temperature to attain a homogeneous reaction mixture. Subsequently, the Teflon vessel was transferred to a stainless steel autoclave, placed upright in an oven, and subjected to heat at 150 °C for 12 h, and then it was allowed to cool down naturally. The as-obtained precipitate was collected by centrifugation and was washed several times with ethanol and water followed by freeze-drying for 24 h.

elements.content: FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT were fabricated by a conventional method as described herein; a fixed amount of pristine NiFe0.5-MOF (for FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF) and NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT (for FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT) precursors was placed in a quartz boat and subjected to annealing at 400 °C in a N2 atmosphere for 1 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. With an intention of comparison, NiFe0.5-MOF@300, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@300, NiFe0.5-MOF@500, and NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@500 have also been prepared at annealing temperatures 300 and 500 °C. Similarly, FeNi3 NPs/MOF was prepared by annealing NiFe0.5-MOF at 400 °C for 30 min and the Fe3O4 NPs/MOF was prepared by heating Fe-MOF at 400 °C for 1 h under a N2 atmosphere.

elements.content: The crystal pattern, lattice parameters, and crystallite sizes of the constructed materials are measured by a Rigaku D/MAX-rA diffractometer with λ = 1.5406 Å (Cu Kα1 radiation), 35 kV, 25 mA, 5°/min from 20 to 80°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements (elemental survey and core-level spectra (C 1s, O 1s, Ni 2p, Fe 2p)) are drawn by Omicron Nanotechnology, Kratos XSAM800, operated at a base pressure of 0.05 × 10–6 bar and 0.3 kW (emission current of 0.02 A, 15 kV) with a 1483 eV, monochromatic Al Kα source. Raman spectra of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT samples (excitation = 532 nm) are recorded using a confocal Raman microscope, Renishaw Corporation. The particle scale and surface morphology of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT are elucidated by VJSM-7000F, JEOL (field-emission scanning electron microscopy, FE-SEM), and using FEI Tecnai G2 F20 (high-resolution transmission electron microscopy, HRTEM) with an accelerating potential difference of 200 kV. The porous behavior and surface area analysis are measured at room temperature (RT) using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) theory (Quantachrome, Nova 2000e).

elements.content: All of the electrocatalytic properties (HER, OER, and water splitting) of these materials were tested in an alkaline solution (1 M KOH) at an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660D) with a standard three-electrode system at ambient temperature (298 K). A home-made three-compartment electrode cell setup is used with a working electrode as constructed electrocatalysts (RuO2, CNT, NiFe x -MOF, NiFe0.5-MOF@300, NiFe0.5-MOF@400, NiFe0.5-MOF@500, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@300, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@400, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@500, FeNi3 NPs/MOF, and Fe3O4 NPs/MOF) modified at the glassy carbon electrode (GCE), the counter electrode as a graphite rod, and the reference electrode as a saturated mercury/mercury oxide (Hg/HgO) in alkaline solution (1 M KOH). Throughout the OER performance, the measured potential values corresponding to Hg/HgO in 1 M KOH were corrected versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) as follows: E RHE = E Hg/HgO + 0.923 V. The overpotential from the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) polarization measurements was calculated based on the E (RHE) – 1.23 V formula. Catalysts are drop-casted onto a 3 mm diameter polished GCE with a loading of ~0.28 mg/cm2, and then dried at 50 °C in an electric hot-oven. Next, 4 mg of as-prepared electrocatalysts is dispersed using a sonoprobe for 10 min in 1 mL of a mixed solution of 3:1 ratio of water/ethanol content (750:250 μL) with 50 μL of Nafion (homogeneously dispersed ink) to achieve the electrocatalyst-modified GCE. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) polarization measurements are performed at 0.005 V/s to find the onset overpotentials (at various current densities (j)). The Tafel slopes were extracted from the corresponding LSV plots in order to access the OER kinetics. Double-layer capacitances (C dl) were also measured from the cyclic voltammogram (CV) in an alkaline solution. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed in the frequency range between 100 kHz and 0.1 Hz. The long-lasting abilities of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT were examined by continuous voltage chronoamperometry using a carbon cloth (1 × 1 cm2). For the overall water-splitting test, a two-electrode setup was constructed by using two aforementioned GCE working electrodes with the same catalyst loading of 0.28 mg/cm2. Faradaic efficiency is another important parameter in the water electrolysis process, which describes the efficiency of electric charge toward facilitating the electrochemical reaction. To calculate the faradaic efficiency, the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT catalyst was loaded on a 1 cm2 carbon cloth (loading: 2 mg/cm2) to conduct HER and OER reactions, and the amounts of oxygen (O2) and hydrogen (H2) released were measured by gas chromatography (GC-2018PT, Shimadzu, argon as the carrier gas) at a constant current of 20 mA. The detailed calculation process is displayed in the Supporting Information (SI). All of the above-mentioned electrochemical studies have been repeated twice to ensure reliability and reproducibility of all of the reported results.

Double-layer capacitances (C

measured from the cyclic voltammogram (CV) in an alkaline solution.
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed in the
frequency range between 100 kHz and 0.1 Hz. The long-lasting abilities
of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT
were examined by continuous voltage chronoamperometry using a carbon
cloth (1 × 1 cm2). For the overall water-splitting
test, a two-electrode setup was constructed by using two aforementioned
GCE working electrodes with the same catalyst loading of 0.28 mg/cm2. Faradaic efficiency is another important parameter in the
water electrolysis process, which describes the efficiency of electric
charge toward facilitating the electrochemical reaction. To calculate
the faradaic efficiency, the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT catalyst was loaded on a 1 cm2 carbon cloth (loading: 2 mg/cm2) to conduct HER and OER
reactions, and the amounts of oxygen (O2) and hydrogen
(H2) released were measured by gas chromatography (GC-2018PT,
Shimadzu, argon as the carrier gas) at a constant current of 20 mA.
The detailed calculation process is displayed in the Supporting Information (SI). All of the above-mentioned electrochemical
studies have been repeated twice to ensure reliability and reproducibility
of all of the reported results.

elements.content: As demonstrated in , the fabrication of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT involves mainly two steps, i.e., construction of a MOF/CNT composite by a hydrothermal method followed by a controlled calcination under a N2 atmosphere. First, the Ni-/Fe-based MOF/CNT composite (NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT) was synthesized by mixing metal salts (Ni2+, Fe3+), 1,4-BDC, and CNT paste in a mixed solution of DMF, ethanol, and water and was stirred at ambient temperature for a uniform distribution followed by hydrothermal treatment at 150 °C for 12 h. Afterward, the as-prepared MOF materials (with/without CNT) were annealed at 300, 400, and 500 °C for 1 h under a N2 atmosphere, during which the pristine MOF materials convert to their respective metal oxide nanoparticle-implanted MOF architectures.

Results and Discussion
Fabrication
of FeNi3–Fe3O4 Nanoparticle-Embedded
Porous MOFs
As demonstrated in , the fabrication
of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT
involves mainly two steps, i.e., construction of a MOF/CNT composite
by a hydrothermal method followed by a controlled calcination under
a N2 atmosphere. First, the Ni-/Fe-based MOF/CNT composite
(NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT) was synthesized by mixing metal salts
(Ni2+, Fe3+), 1,4-BDC, and CNT paste in a mixed
solution of DMF, ethanol, and water and was stirred at ambient temperature
for a uniform distribution followed by hydrothermal treatment at 150
°C for 12 h. Afterward, the as-prepared MOF materials (with/without
CNT) were annealed at 300, 400, and 500 °C for 1 h under a N2 atmosphere, during which the pristine MOF materials convert
to their respective metal oxide nanoparticle-implanted MOF architectures.

elements.content: The crystal structure features of obtained materials were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis. The associated powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns for the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT are shown in a, where the bimetallic MOF (NiFe0.5-MOF) and its CNT composite (NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT) prepared display similar XRD patterns with Fe-MIL-88B (CCDC no. 1415803; Figure S1a), demonstrating the successful construction of a MIL-type architecture via a solvothermal process. The corresponding characteristic diffraction peaks of the annealed samples at 400 °C confirmed the presence of two different phases, i.e., FeNi3 alloy and Fe3O4 nanoparticles in NiFe0.5-MOF and its CNT composite. The XRD patterns of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT match with cubic FeNi3 (44.27° (111), 51.53° (200), and 75.86° (220), JCPDS PDF# 38-0419) with a highly symmetric space group Pm3̅m (221), and the remaining diffraction peaks are indexed to cubic Fe3O4 (30.09° (220), 35.42° (311), 43.05° (400), 56.94° (511), and 62.51° (440), JCPDS PDF# 19-0629) with a highly symmetric space group Fd3̅m (227). As shown in a, the XRD diffraction peaks belonging to the pristine MOF or the MOF/CNT composite still remain in the annealed samples, demonstrating the persistence of the crystalline bimetallic MOF structure even after annealing treatment as we intended (evidenced by the (100) plane at 9.09°). Attempts to prepare nanoparticles within the MOF architecture at higher temperatures, such as at 500 °C, for 1 h under a N2 atmosphere led to the complete decomposition of the MOF skeleton and produced Fe3O4 and FeNi3 heterostructural nanoparticles (Figure S1b). Particularly, the diffraction peaks assigned to Fe3O4 were not clearly noticed in the XRD pattern compared to FeNi3, which may be due to the small grain size and concise diffraction peak intensity of Fe3O4. Similarly, NiFe0.5-MOF after annealing displayed the XRD patterns of FeNi3 and Fe3O4 heterogeneous particles within the MOF skeleton (FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF). Besides, diffraction peaks corresponding to CNT are not quite noticeable in XRD, while they were clearly evidenced by Raman spectroscopy.

elements.content: As displayed in b, the prominent Raman bands in the region of 1300–1700 cm–1 are assigned to the characteristic D and G bands of the carbon skeleton (CNT, peaks at ∼1350 cm–1 correspond to the edge-associated hybridized vibrational mode (D-band) and those at ∼1600 cm–1 are ascribed to sp2 vibrations (G band)). Similarly, the carbon skeleton-encapsulated FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (NiFe0.5-MOF@400) electrocatalyst also displays visible Raman bands related to the organic ligand/carbon moiety as expected. BET analysis was carried out to compare and get better information about the accessible surface properties (surface area and porous behaviors) of NiFe0.5-MOF, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF, and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT materials, through the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm, as presented in c,d.

elements.content: The hysteresis diagram of NiFe0.5-MOF, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF, and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT reflects surface areas of 84.11, 154.74, 31.77, and 104.15 m2/g, respectively. The average N2-adsorption pore diameters are 13.03, 7.62, 14.22, and 14.46 nm (4 V/A by BET) for NiFe0.5-MOF, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF, and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT, respectively. The inclusion of CNT with NiFe0.5-MOF shows a high surface area than the materials without CNT addition (c,d and S2), whereas the obtained results endorse the mesoporous behaviors of materials with a greatly enlarged surface area, which is consistent with the earlier reports on materials anchored by CNT. More essentially, BET analysis reveals the existence of the surface area of annealed samples to that of pristine MOF materials. FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (31.77 m2/g) engaged 37.8% of the initial specific surface area of its pristine NiFe0.5-MOF (84.11 m2/g), while FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (104.15 m2/g) retained 67.3% of the initial specific surface area of the NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT composite (154.74 m2/g), thus confirming the existence of the microporous nature of NiFe0.5-MOF and NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT after controlled pyrolysis.

elements.content: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted to further investigate the composition information of materials. The analysis revealed the coexistence of Ni, Fe, O, and C elements in FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT. The high-resolution XPS spectra of Ni 2p and Fe 2p were further analyzed, and the data of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT are presented in (Figures S3 and S4). The Ni 2p peak located at 855.69 eV in the XPS spectrum indicates the valence state of +2 in FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT, the typical Fe 2p peaks at 710.9 and 724.0 eV () represent the oxidation state of +2, and the peaks at 714.4 and 726.1 eV confirm the presence of the +3 oxidation state of iron in Fe3O4. The high-resolution Ni 2p emission spectra (Ni 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 with binding energy difference ΔE g = 17.81 eV) can be deconvoluted in between the range of 850 and 885 eV into two strong bands with parallel satellite peaks (a). Besides, a typical Ni0 peak appeared at 852.6 and 870.01 eV for FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT, which confirms the presence of FeNi3 particles. Similarly, the Fe 2p emission spectrum (Fe 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 with binding energy differences ΔE = 13.1 eV) also appears in between the binding energies of 700 and 735 eV and was deconvoluted into four strong peaks with corresponding satellite peaks at 719.6 and 732.4 eV, which further provides very good agreement with the characteristics of typical Fe3O4 nanoparticles. In addition, small peaks at 706.52 and 722.4 eV signify the presence of Fe0 in FeNi3.

elements.content: The high-resolution O 1s spectrum of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT is deconvoluted into three peaks, located at 533.7, 531.4, and 530 eV, which are assigned to the adsorbed water, hydroxyl groups or oxygen vacancies, and lattice O2 –, respectively. Similarly, the C 1s emission spectrum is deconvoluted into four bands located at 284.5, 285.3, 286.7, and 288.6 eV relating to sp2-hybridized graphitic carbon (CC), C–O/C–C, CO, and oxygen-rich groups (OC–O), respectively. FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF also demonstrates similar XPS data as expected (Figure S4). As an outcome, more electrocatalytically active sites are exposed due to the uniform dispersion of small FeNi3 and Fe3O4 particles on the CNT and pristine MOF surface, which are believed to be beneficial for the effective electrocatalytic water-splitting process.

elements.content: Electron microscopy techniques were employed to study the nanostructures of NiFe0.5-MOF and NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT before and after the annealing treatment. The surface micro-/nanostructures of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT were detailed through scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and transmission electron microscope (TEM) images as displayed in b (Figure S5). This morphology study revealed the 2D structural arrangement of MOF materials prepared herein (NiFe0.5-MOF and NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT) and was strongly supported by recently reported Ni-/Fe-bimetallic 2D MOF nanosheets, i.e., Ni and Fe or Cu 2D MOF nanosheets reported by Zhao et al., Ni0.75Fe0.25 BDC reported by Li and co-workers, and the Ni-MOF@Fe-MOF hybrid by Dou et al. TEM images also further indicated the same observations that the compact FeNi3 and Fe3O4 particles uniformly decorated throughout the CNT walls and MOF nanosheets as displayed in b. A similar phenomenon was also noticed in MOF-74 upon partial oxidation, which led to the dispersion of the NiCo alloy and Fe3O4 heterostructural nanoparticles within MOF nanosheets. Furthermore, the high-resolution TEM well-resolved lattice fringes obtained for FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (c) confirm the presence of FeNi3 and Fe3O4 heterogeneous particles in porous pristine MOFs along with the 1D CNTs matrix. Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental analysis (Figure S6), scanning TEM (STEM) (d), and elemental area mapping images for FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (e–h) and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (Figure S5) give a better notion that the elements Fe, Ni, C, and O are uniformly dispersed over the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT samples, which are also in good agreement with the XPS results.

elements.content: Ni-/Fe-based electrocatalysts have demonstrated great potential in replacing precious-metal-based catalysts, particularly in the process of the oxygen evolution reaction, due to their unique physicochemical abilities, earth-abundant nature, and low cost. Particularly, in Ni-/Fe-based electrocatalysts, nickel is considered as the active metal center for oxygen evolution, while the incorporation of iron would lead to the existence of a synergistic effect, followed by changes in intrinsic properties of mixed-metal catalysts, thus promoting the OER performance. Ni-/Fe-bimetallic MOFs isolated in this study can directly be used as electrocatalysts to investigate their OER performance without any annealing treatment as reported earlier. The OER performance of as-prepared NiFe x -MOF (x = 0.75, 0.5, 0.25) was evaluated with a typical three-electrode system in an O2-saturated 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution at room temperature (Figure S7a). The potential values are calibrated against the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Among the bimetallic NiFe x -MOFs prepared, NiFe0.5-MOF displayed the best OER performance with the overpotential of 281 mV at the current density of 10 mA/cm2.

nickel is considered as the active metal center for oxygen evolution,
while the incorporation of iron would lead to the existence of a synergistic

catalysts, thus promoting the OER performance. Ni-/Fe-bimetallic MOFs isolated in this study can directly
be used as electrocatalysts to investigate their OER performance without
any annealing treatment as reported earlier. The OER performance of as-prepared NiFe
x
-MOF (x = 0.75, 0.5, 0.25)

NiFe

-MOFs prepared, NiFe0.5-MOF displayed the best OER performance with the overpotential of
281 mV at the current density of 10 mA/cm2.

elements.content: Consequently, the best bimetallic MOF has been subjected to controlled partial oxidation to prepare the nanoparticle-embedded MOFs and to realize the annealing effect on electrocatalysis. In controlled experiments, the influence of different annealing temperatures (300, 400, and 500 °C, samples denoted NiFe0.5-MOF@300, NiFe0.5-MOF@400 (confirmed as FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF), and NiFe0.5-MOF@500) of the samples was tested by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements (Figure S7b). The optimal annealing temperature of the sample for OER performance was 400 °C, and the NiFe0.5-MOF@400 displayed improved OER performance with 261 mV overpotential at the current density of 10 mA/cm2, which is considerably better than the as-prepared MOF due to the existence of FeNi3–Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs). Keeping this improved performance in mind, the CNT-anchored bimetallic MOF composite (NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT) has been prepared and was subjected to controlled partial oxidation at 300, 400, and 500 °C (denoted NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@300, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@400, and NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@500) under a N2 flow to prepare CNT-anchored FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF in the MOF architecture. Among them, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@400 (confirmed as FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT) displayed phenomenal OER performance (Figure S9a) compared to the bimetallic MOFs prepared without CNT and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF prepared by partial annealing treatment. The commercial RuO2, bare glassy carbon electrode, and pure CNT were also tested for comparison.

in the MOF architecture. Among them, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@400
(confirmed as FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT)
displayed phenomenal OER performance (Figure S9a) compared to the bimetallic MOFs prepared without CNT and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF prepared by partial
annealing treatment. The commercial RuO2, bare glassy carbon
electrode, and pure CNT were also tested for comparison.

elements.content: As expected, RuO2 displays a good OER activity with an overpotential of 271 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm2, whereas the bare glassy carbon electrode and CNT do not display OER activity, which was consistent with previous reports. It was evidently found that the NiFe0.5-MOF, NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF, and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT all exhibit superior OER activity (a). Among them, the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (R = 8.10 Ω) electrocatalyst displays the best OER performance with the smallest onset overpotential of 108 mV (versus RHE), achieving the current density of 10 mV/cm2 at an overpotential (η10) of 234 mV in alkaline solution, which was lower than that of NiFe0.5-MOF (281 mV; R = 8.26 Ω), NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT (271 mV; R = 7.06 Ω), and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (261 mV; R = 8.35 Ω). Moreover, as shown in , compared to commercial CNT, NiFe0.5-MOF, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF, and NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT, the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT synthesized by controlled partial oxidation of NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT shows the best OER performance in alkaline solution, which is mainly attributed to the unique nanostructural architecture and the synergistic effect of the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT electrocatalyst together with the modification of the surface electronic state of FeNi3 caused by the Fe3O4. However, the as-prepared FeNi3 (η10 = 358 mV) and Fe3O4 (η10 = 406 mV) nanoparticles have not displayed significant OER activity. Besides, the recent theoretical calculation studies on electrocatalysts also approve the possible electronic modification in heterogeneous nanoparticles, which can enhance the catalytic performance. However, the experimental innovations confirmed that the heterogeneous nanoparticles indeed improve the catalytic performance due to the modification of the electronic structure. In this study, to scrutinize the strong electron interaction between FeNi3 and Fe3O4, which is able to improve the “electrophilicity of NiFe0.5-MOF@400 (Fe3O4–FeNi3 NPs/MOF)”, we prepared new samples of Fe3O4 NPs/MOF and FeNi3 NPs/MOF and measured their catalytic performance for comparison. As shown in Figure S8, one can observe that the performance of Fe3O4–FeNi3 NPs/MOF (NiFe0.5-MOF@400; η10 = 261 mV) is better than those of Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (η10 = 341 mV) and FeNi3 NPs/MOF (η10 = 316 mV). This OER activity test suggests the existence of strong interactions between FeNi3 and Fe3O4, which can improve the catalytic performance.

elements.content: Besides, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (234 mV at current density of 10 mA/cm2) displays much better overpotential over the nickel–copper nanoparticle-encapsulated MOF-74 (590 mV) and Fe3O4-decorated iron/nickel alloy nanoparticles on graphene sheets (274 mV), and it is as good as the overpotentials reported for Fe3O4-decorated nickel/cobalt alloy nanoparticles on MOF-74 (238 mV) and the FeNi3 alloy-decorated NiFeO x nanohybrid (240 mV). All of these reports suggest the significance of the presence of heterostructural nanoparticles in a material to obtain the optimal electrocatalytic activity. Tafel slopes of materials have been derived from respective LSV plots to get clear information about the reaction mechanism (b and S9b). The equation h = b log j + a was used to fit the Tafel slopes, in which “j” stands for current density and “b” stands for the Tafel slope. FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT has a Tafel slope as small as 37.0 mV/dec, which is smaller than the materials prepared herein, and that of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (42.4 mV/dec) and RuO2 is 57.5 mV/dec, signifying its quick reaction kinetics. Besides, the steady current at each potential was used to obtain the actual Tafel slope (38.3 mV/dec; Figures S13 and S14) of the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material. The obtained Tafel slope is found to be slightly higher than the Tafel slope derived from its LSV curve. In addition, the amount of oxygen generated during the water oxidation process and its faradaic efficiency were also detected by loading (2 mg/cm2) the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material on the 1 cm2 carbon cloth. As displayed in Figure S21, the measured amounts of O2 match well with the theoretical values. The faradaic efficiency of the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT electrode for O2 generation is 98.5%, indicating that the introduced electric charge is completely used for the water oxidation process.

elements.content: The continuous cyclic voltammetry scanning test carried out on FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT to obtain a better understanding on the long-lasting abilities of the material and the closely overlapped LSV plots at the first cycle and after the 5000th CV cycle suggest the excellent stability of the material (c). Moreover, the durable behavior of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT was also trailed at a static overpotential of 234 mV chronoamperometric in 1 M KOH solution, which also demonstrates the negligible loss in current density with excellent durability for 20 h (d). Based on the above results, the outstanding physiochemical stability/durability was realized as anticipated, which has been considered as one of the crucial criteria for OER electrocatalysis and was the major drawback in most of the MOF materials reported for the OER process. To further investigate the surface status and overall structure (morphology and composition changes) of the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material during the water oxidation process, SEM and XPS characterizations were performed after a 20 h i–t test and also XRD and XPS tests were performed after 5000 CV cycles. Figure S15 displays the SEM images of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT before and after the OER process. Obviously, the nanosheets, like the CNT network structure, well remained after the i–t test, demonstrating robust structural stability. As it was evidenced earlier for Ni-based electrocatalysts, the actual active species could be nickel hydroxide during the OER process. To have a clear understanding of the active species during the OER process, the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT after the 20 h i–t test was subjected to XPS analysis. The high-resolution XPS core-level spectra of Ni 2p and Fe 2p regions of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT after the i–t test revealed the existence of Ni0, Ni2+, Fe0, Fe2+, and Fe3+ ions, which signifies the phenomenal stability of the material during the OER process (Figure S16). Similar XPS results have been obtained for FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT after 5000 CV cycles during the OER process (Figure S17). In addition to this, the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material after 5000 CV cycles for OER was analyzed by the powder XRD technique. As presented in Figure S18, the FeNi3 (JCPDS PDF# 38-0419) and Fe3O4 (JCPDS PDF# 19-0629) heterostructural nanoparticles still exist in the material, signifying its phenomenal stability during OER processes in the alkaline solution. Interestingly, the XRD peak corresponding to the MOF material [at 9.09° (100)] did not appear, which can be attributed to the small grain size and concise diffraction peak intensity of the MOF material in the sample.

elements.content: To further clarify the high OER activity of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT, the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) was evaluated in a non-faradaic capacitive current range by operating cyclic voltammograms to estimate the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) (a and S10). The capacitance of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (1.63 mF/cm2) was larger than that of the NiFe0.5-MOF (0.13 mF/cm2), NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT (0.21 mF/cm2), and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (0.84 mF/cm2), demonstrating its large surface area with highly exposed active centers for the OER process (a). Moreover, the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT is estimated by conducting cyclic voltammograms after the 20 h i–t test to investigate the active sites and specific surface area. Interestingly, the C dl value detected after the i–t test (1.62 mF/cm2; Figure S19) is almost the same as the C dl value estimated before the i–t test, suggesting the similar active sites and specific surface area. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was also conducted to investigate the catalytic kinetics under the OER process. Nyquist plots of NiFe0.5-MOF (71.9 Ω), NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT (39.61 Ω), and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (18.98 Ω) are higher than FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (13.2 Ω), suggesting the least charge transfer resistance, which is in accordance with the result of its large surface area (BET), C dl values, and lower Tafel slope. Although FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (1.63 mF/cm2) has a higher ECSA value over FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (0.84 mF/cm2), the specific activity calculated by normalizing the current to the ECSA was found to be almost the same for both the electrocatalysts (Figure S12b), signifying the similar intrinsic catalytic abilities during the OER process. Obviously, the higher C dl value and the presence of the conductive CNT matrix in FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT as well as the significantly lowered charge transfer resistance (13.2 Ω) clearly emphasize the boost in the catalytic active surface area, which can be attributed to the interface coupling effect between the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs and the CNT support.

elements.content: Besides, the obtained ECSA values of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (0.84 mF/cm2) and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (1.63 mF/cm2) together with their retained surface areas (31.77 and 104.15 m2/g, respectively) after controlled thermal treatment suggested that most of the active metal sites in the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF material would have been embedded in the bulk phase produced due to the substantial decomposition, thereby displaying lower efficiency during the OER process. While the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF–CNT material displays enhanced OER performance than the material prepared without CNTs (FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF) is mainly due to the existence of larger surface area even after annealing, which results in the homogeneous distribution of active nanoparticles within MOF nanosheets and 1D CNTs matrix for improved mass transfer, thereby exhibits enhanced ECSA followed by improved OER performance. Although these annealed samples (FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF) show similar or slightly reduced specific activity than the as-prepared MOF and its CNT composite, the largely increased active area and greatly reduced charge transfer resistance are the potential motives for their higher performance in the OER process.

elements.content: Recent research innovations on Ni-/Fe-based electrocatalysts demonstrated that the nickel metal is considered as the active center for the water-splitting process and the incorporation of iron can alter the electronic states of Ni (Ni3+/Ni2+) and thereby significantly enhance the electrocatalytic activity. Recently, Wang et al. have noticed the electronic state modification in Ni (Ni3+/Ni2+) in MoO x -decorated NiFe-alloy nanosheets. Similarly, Lin et al. observed the modification of electronic states in Ni (Ni3+/Ni2+) of FeNi3 by Fe3O4 heterostructural particles anchored on a laser-induced graphene. In addition, Zhu et al. demonstrated the improved OER activity of Fe3O4@NiS x /reduced graphene oxide (rGO) composites and have considered that the −M–OH and/or −M–OOH are the active species (M can be either Ni or Fe) and summarized that the combination of Fe and Ni species would provide improved electrical conductivity for Ni-/Fe-based materials. Besides, Boettcher et al. reported that the Ni-containing hydroxide/oxyhydroxide phases are identified as the active catalyst in the Ni0.9Fe0.1O x material. Therefore, it is believed that the Ni of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT is expected to form a Ni–OH bond first from the adsorbed water molecule as nickel is considered as the active species in Ni-/Fe-based electrocatalysts for the OER process and the presence of Fe3O4 particles is expected to alter the electronic states of Ni, thereby making the nickel metal more electrophilic and consequently making the adsorbed oxygen species more electrophilic to attract another unit of OH– to form Ni–OOH, whose formation step is considered as the rate-determining step (RDS). After this, the adsorbed oxygen induces the deprotonation of *OOH units by means of a negative inductive effect (electron-withdrawing nature) to generate O2 molecules.

OER Mechanistic Investigations
Recent research innovations
on Ni-/Fe-based electrocatalysts demonstrated that the nickel metal
is considered as the active center for the water-splitting process
and the incorporation of iron can alter the electronic states of Ni
(Ni3+/Ni2+) and thereby significantly enhance
the electrocatalytic activity. Recently, Wang et al. have noticed the electronic state modification
in Ni (Ni3+/Ni2+) in MoO
x
-decorated NiFe-alloy nanosheets. Similarly, Lin et al. observed the modification of electronic states
in Ni (Ni3+/Ni2+) of FeNi3 by Fe3O4 heterostructural particles anchored on a laser-induced
graphene. In addition, Zhu et al. demonstrated the
improved OER activity of Fe3O4@NiS
x
/reduced graphene oxide (rGO) composites and have
considered that the −M–OH and/or −M–OOH
are the active species (M can be either Ni or Fe) and summarized that
the combination of Fe and Ni species would provide improved electrical
conductivity for Ni-/Fe-based materials. Besides, Boettcher et al. reported that the Ni-containing hydroxide/oxyhydroxide
phases are identified as the active catalyst in the Ni0.9Fe0.1O
x
 material. Therefore, it is believed that the Ni of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT is expected
to form a Ni–OH bond first from the adsorbed water molecule
as nickel is considered as the active species in Ni-/Fe-based electrocatalysts
for the OER process and the presence of Fe3O4 particles is expected to alter the electronic states of Ni, thereby
making the nickel metal more electrophilic and consequently making
the adsorbed oxygen species more electrophilic to attract another
unit of OH– to form Ni–OOH, whose formation
step is considered as the rate-determining step (RDS). After this, the adsorbed oxygen induces the deprotonation of *OOH
units by means of a negative inductive effect (electron-withdrawing
nature) to generate O2 molecules.

elements.content: The aforementioned mechanistic hypothesis (Ni–OOH formation as the rate-determining step) was further supported by electrokinetic studies on FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT electrocatalysts in 0.5 M phosphate-buffered solution at pH = 7 (Figure S22). The Tafel slopes derived from the corresponding LSV plots are 74.11 and 70.02 mV/dec, respectively. This suggests the possible reversible one-electron transfer process prior to the rate-determining step (RDS). While the pH-dependent experiments (under a neutral pH range from 6.5, 7.0, 7.5, and 8.0; Figure S23) on FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT suggested the quasi-equilibrium reversible 1e–/1H+ transfer step followed by the RDS, a similar such effect has been observed for MnO nanoparticles under neutral conditions. These results have suggested that the formation of Ni–OOH is the rate-determining step in the water oxidation process (Figure S23d). However, additional experimental and theoretical studies are necessary to realize the mechanistic pathway of the water oxidation process.

under neutral conditions. These results have suggested
that the formation of Ni–OOH is the rate-determining step in
the water oxidation process (Figure S23d). However, additional experimental and theoretical
studies are necessary to realize the mechanistic pathway of the water
oxidation process.

elements.content: Recent research findings demonstrate the efficient bifunctional activity of transition-metal-based oxides. Besides the excellent OER activity of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT, it also exhibits considerable HER activity in 1 M KOH aqueous electrolyte. As displayed in a, the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT displays the best HER activity within the samples we have prepared and tested. The overpotential of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT was only 108 mV (R = 6.86 Ω) at a current density of 10 mA/cm2, which outperforms the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (228 mV; R = 7.11 Ω), NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT (419 mV; R = 7.06 Ω), NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@300 (270 mV), and NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT@500 (241 mV), and is comparable with the commercial Pt/C catalyst (43 mV) (a and S12a). The FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT overpotential (108 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm2) is almost comparable to the overpotentials reported with carbon fiber paper (CFP)-supported NiFeO x (88 mV), FeNi3 alloy-decorated NiFeO x nanohybrids (99 mV), and the bifunctional octahedral Co3O4 catalyst (77.9 mV).

elements.content: The corresponding Tafel slope of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT was found to be as low as 96.75 mV/dec compared to the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF material (100.11 mV/dec), indicating that this material possesses relatively fast reaction kinetics in HER as well (b and S11b,c). Besides, the steady current at each potential was used to obtain the actual Tafel slope (101.4 mV/dec; Figures S13 and S14) of the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material. The obtained Tafel slope is found to be slightly higher than the Tafel slope derived from its LSV curve. The continuous cyclic voltammetry scanning test was performed to determine the stability of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (c), which displays a similar polarization curve even after the 5000th CV cycle. The closely overlapped curves indicate the outstanding stability of the catalyst. In addition, the long-lasting behavior of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT was also tested at a static overpotential of 108 mV chronoamperometric in 1 M KOH solution, which demonstrates the insignificant loss in current density with excellent durability for 20 h (d). These results demonstrate the excellent long-lasting abilities of the newly prepared catalyst. The Nyquist plot of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (61.38 Ω) shows a significantly smaller charge transfer resistance (Figure S12c) compared with FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (190.7 Ω), NiFe0.5-MOF/CNT (538.0 Ω), and NiFe0.5-MOF (1927 Ω), which is in good accordance with the result of its better performance with a small Tafel slope, higher specific surface area, and large ESCA. In contrast to the OER performance, the higher ECSA value of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (1.63 mF/cm2) during the HER process signifies its higher specific activity by normalizing the current to the ECSA (Figure S12a). This indicates the superior intrinsic catalytic activity of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT over other electrocatalysts prepared herein for the HER process, which is in accordance with its high ECSA, lower charge transfer resistance, and also the smaller Tafel slope.

elements.content: The aforementioned results signify very well the HER performance of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/CNT, which can be fairly ascribed to the decoration of FeNi3 and Fe3O4 heterogeneous particles on the CNT network. The typical HER mechanism (in alkaline medium) includes a three-step process as follows Volmer  reaction : H 2 O + active  site + e − → H * + OH − Heyrovsky reaction : H 2 O + H * + e − → H 2 ↑ + OH − Tafel  reaction: 2 H * → H 2 ↑ The Tafel slopes of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (96.75 mV/dec) and FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF (100.11 mV/dec) suggest the accomplishment of the Volmer–Heyrovsky type of reaction kinetics for the HER process on the electrocatalysts used in this study. Similarly, the amount of hydrogen generated during the water electrolysis process and its faradaic efficiency were also detected by loading (2 mg/cm2) the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material on the 1 cm2 carbon cloth. As displayed in Figure S19, the measured amounts of H2 match well with the theoretical values. The faradaic efficiency of the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT electrode for H2 generation is 96.8%, suggesting that the introduced electric charge is completely used for the water electrolysis process.

elements.content: The superior electrocatalytic activity of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT for both OER and HER processes unveils its exceptional potential as a bifunctional catalyst for overall water splitting. Therefore, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT was used to prepare GCE-modified electrocatalysts with the same catalyst loading of 0.28 mg/cm2, which are used as both the anode and cathode to construct a two-electrode cell in an alkaline medium to investigate the water-splitting ability. The FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT electrocatalyst displayed an overpotential of 360 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA/cm2 and is consistent with the sum of overpotentials of its HER (108 mV) and OER (234 mV) at the same current density (a), while the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF developed without CNTs displayed an overpotential of 449 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2. Interestingly, our best catalyst outperforms the water-splitting ability of the benchmark precious-metal catalyst combination (Pt/C: cathode; RuO2: anode), which displays an overpotential of 393 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2 (b). This study demonstrated the significance of a conductive CNT matrix in developing MOF-derived electrocatalysts for overall water splitting than the materials prepared without conductive additives including CNTs, graphene oxide, and so on. A similar effect has been noticed recently by MOF-derived layered reduced graphene oxide-supported CoP (CoP/rGO-400) with an overpotential of 470 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm2, which actually outperforms the noble-metal combination (Pt/C and IrO2; η10 is 480 mV) in overall water splitting.

Overall Water Splitting
The superior
electrocatalytic
activity of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT
for both OER and HER processes unveils its exceptional potential as
a bifunctional catalyst for overall water splitting. Therefore, FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT was used to prepare GCE-modified electrocatalysts
with the same catalyst loading of 0.28 mg/cm2, which are
used as both the anode and cathode to construct a two-electrode cell
in an alkaline medium to investigate the water-splitting ability.
The FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT
electrocatalyst displayed an overpotential of 360 mV to reach a current
density of 10 mA/cm2 and is consistent with the sum of
overpotentials of its HER (108 mV) and OER (234 mV) at the same current
density (a),
while the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF
developed without CNTs displayed an overpotential of 449 mV to achieve
a current density of 10 mA/cm2. Interestingly, our best
catalyst outperforms the water-splitting ability of the benchmark
precious-metal catalyst combination (Pt/C: cathode; RuO2: anode), which displays an overpotential of 393 mV to achieve a
current density of 10 mA/cm2 (b). This study demonstrated the significance
of a conductive CNT matrix in developing MOF-derived electrocatalysts
for overall water splitting than the materials prepared without conductive
additives including CNTs, graphene oxide, and so on. A similar effect
has been noticed recently by MOF-derived layered reduced graphene
oxide-supported CoP (CoP/rGO-400) with an overpotential of 470 mV
at a current density of 10 mA/cm2, which actually outperforms
the noble-metal combination (Pt/C and IrO2; η10 is 480 mV) in overall water splitting.

elements.content: Besides this, the excellent water-splitting ability of FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT (360 mV) is in great agreement with other transition-metal-based oxide bifunctional catalysts reported recently, i.e., FeNi3/NiFeO x nanohybrid (320 mV), octahedral Co3O4 electrocatalyst (370 mV), carbon fiber paper-supported NiFeO x (NiFeO x /CFP) (280 mV), and the other metal alloys decorated MOF derivatives. Under the constructed double electrode system, a continuous cyclic voltammetry scanning test was also carried out on the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material to better understand its long-lasting abilities; the closely overlapped LSV plots at the first cycle and after the 5000th CV cycle indicate the excellent stability of the material (c). Similarly, a durability test was conducted at a static overpotential of 360 mV chronoamperometric in 1 M KOH solution on the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material, which displayed 20 h of durability without any significant activity decay, suggesting its long-lasting operational abilities in an alkaline medium (c). Moreover, the SEM analysis of the FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT material after the 20 h durability test displays an almost similar nanosheet morphology as before the electrolysis, signifying the robust structural stability of the material (Figure S20).

elements.content: In this work, we have demonstrated a controlled annealing process to develop a unique FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT electrocatalyst for efficient HER, OER, and overall water splitting in alkaline media. The hybrid MOF composite takes advantage of MOF porous architectures and the interaction between the mixed-metal alloy (FeNi3) and metal oxide (Fe3O4) nanoparticles formed by controlled thermal treatment and displays exceptional performance and durability as a bifunctional electrocatalyst toward overall water splitting. The FeNi3 and Fe3O4 particles with amended electronic properties on electrodes are attained due to the rational design of interfaces (MOF with FeNi3, Fe3O4, CNT), which could overcome the sluggish kinetic barriers by means of less aggregation of active sites and provide the desired surface architecture, thereby leading to the excellent charge transfer property. In addition, the Fe3O4-rich CNT support would provide electron density to metallic FeNi3 active sites to maintain its stability during long-term analysis (i–t test). The newly developed FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT displays 234 mV overpotential at a current density of 10 mA/cm2 with a small Tafel slope of 37.0 mV/dec, which outperforms the other similar electrocatalyst prepared without the CNT matrix (FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF). Similarly, it also outperforms the benchmark precious-metal combination in overall water splitting. Therefore, we believe that this controlled thermal treatment strategy can afford a new perception toward the isolation of nanoparticle-implanted MOF-based electrocatalysts, which would enhance the widespread opportunities of MOFs and MOF-based derivatives and pave the path to designing extremely efficient electrocatalysts. We also believe that these obtained results pave a way toward the ease of fabrication of potentially desirable materials composed of earth-abundant non-noble elements.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In this work, we have demonstrated a controlled annealing process
to develop a unique FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT electrocatalyst for efficient HER, OER, and overall
water splitting in alkaline media. The hybrid MOF composite takes
advantage of MOF porous architectures and the interaction between
the mixed-metal alloy (FeNi3) and metal oxide (Fe3O4) nanoparticles formed by controlled thermal treatment
and displays exceptional performance and durability as a bifunctional
electrocatalyst toward overall water splitting. The FeNi3 and Fe3O4 particles with amended electronic
properties on electrodes are attained due to the rational design of
interfaces (MOF with FeNi3, Fe3O4, CNT), which could overcome the sluggish kinetic barriers by means
of less aggregation of active sites and provide the desired surface
architecture, thereby leading to the excellent charge transfer property.
In addition, the Fe3O4-rich CNT support would
provide electron density to metallic FeNi3 active sites
to maintain its stability during long-term analysis (i–t test). The newly developed FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF-CNT displays 234 mV overpotential
at a current density of 10 mA/cm2 with a small Tafel slope
of 37.0 mV/dec, which outperforms the other similar electrocatalyst
prepared without the CNT matrix (FeNi3–Fe3O4 NPs/MOF). Similarly, it also outperforms the benchmark
precious-metal combination in overall water splitting. Therefore,
we believe that this controlled thermal treatment strategy can afford
a new perception toward the isolation of nanoparticle-implanted MOF-based
electrocatalysts, which would enhance the widespread opportunities
of MOFs and MOF-based derivatives and pave the path to designing extremely
efficient electrocatalysts. We also believe that these obtained results
pave a way toward the ease of fabrication of potentially desirable
materials composed of earth-abundant non-noble elements.
